column2: The sky was grey, but that made little difference in the Piazza del Duomo, which was covered with its holiday sky of blue drapery, and its constellations of yellow lilies and coats of arms.

column2: The sheaves of banners were unfurled at the angles of the Baptistery, but there was no carpet yet on the steps of the Duomo, for the marble was being trodden by numerous feet that were not at all exceptional.
column3: The sheaves of banners were unfurled at the angles of the Baptistery, but there was no carpet yet on the steps of the Duomo, for the marble was being trodden by numerous feet that were not at all exceptional.

column2: It was the hour of the Advent sermons, and the very same reasons which had flushed the streets with holiday colour were reasons why the preaching in the Duomo could least of all be dispensed with.

column2: At the corner, looking towards the Via de' Cerretani--just where the artificial rainbow light of the Piazza ceased, and the grey morning fell on the sombre stone houses--there was a remarkable cluster of the working people, most of them bearing on their dress or persons the signs of their daily labour, and almost all of them carrying some weapon, or some tool which might serve as a weapon upon occasion.

column2: They were listening to the thin notary, Ser Cioni, who had just paused on his way to the Duomo.

column2: Never talk to me, he was saying, in his incisive voice, "never talk to me of bloodthirsty Swiss or fierce French infantry: they might as well be in the narrow passes of the mountains as in our streets; and peasants have destroyed the finest armies of our condottieri in time past, when they had once got them between steep precipices.

column2: I tell you, Florentines need be afraid of no army in their own streets."

column2: That's true, Ser Cioni, said a man whose arms and hands were discoloured by crimson dye, which looked like blood-stains, and who had a small hatchet stuck in his belt; "and those French cavaliers, who came in squaring themselves in their smart doublets the other day, saw a sample of the dinner we could serve up for them.

column2: I was carrying my cloth in Ognissanti, when I saw my fine Messeri going by, looking round as if they thought the houses of the Vespucci and the Agli a poor pick of lodgings for them, and eyeing us Florentines, like top-knotted cocks as they are, as if they pitied us because we didn't know how to strut. `Yes, my fine _Galli_,' says I, `stick out your stomachs; I've got a meat-axe in my belt that will go inside you all the easier;' when presently the old cow lowed, [Note 1] and I knew something had happened--no matter what.

column2: The advancing party was rather a brilliant one, for there was not only the distinguished presence of Lorenzo Tornabuoni, and the splendid costume of the Frenchman with his elaborately displayed white linen and gorgeous embroidery; there were two other Florentines of high birth in handsome dresses donned for the coming procession, and on the left-hand of the Frenchman was a figure that was not to be eclipsed by any amount of intention or brocade--a figure we have often seen before.
column3: The advancing party was rather a brilliant one, for there was not only the distinguished presence of Lorenzo Tornabuoni, and the splendid costume of the Frenchman with his elaborately displayed white linen and gorgeous embroidery; there were two other Florentines of high birth in handsome dresses donned for the coming procession, and on the left hand of the Frenchman was a figure that was not to be eclipsed by any amount of intention or brocade-a figure we have often seen before.

column2: He wore nothing but black, for he was in mourning; but the black was presently to be covered by a red mantle, for he too was to walk in procession as Latin Secretary to the Ten.

column3: The lustre of good fortune was upon him; he was smiling, listening, and explaining, with his usual graceful unpretentious ease, and only a very keen eye bent on studying him could have marked a certain amount of change in him which was not to be accounted for by the lapse of eighteen months.

column2: It was that change which comes from the final departure of moral youthfulness--from the distinct self-conscious adoption of a part in life.
column3: It was that change which comes from the final departure of moral youthfulness-from the distinct self conscious adoption of a part in life.

column2: The lines of the face were as soft as ever, the eyes as pellucid; but something was gone--something as indefinable as the changes in the morning twilight.
column3: The lines of the face were as soft as ever, the eyes as pellucid; but something was gone-something as indefinable as the changes in the morning twilight.

column2: The Frenchman was gathering instructions concerning ceremonial before riding back to Signa, and now he was going to have a final survey of the Piazza del Duomo, where the royal procession was to pause for religious purposes.
column3: The Frenchman was gathering instructions concerning ceremonial before riding back to Signa, and now he was going to have a final survey of the Piazza del Duomo, where the royal procession was to pause for religious purposes.

column2: The distinguished party attracted the notice of all eyes as it entered the piazza, but the gaze was not entirely cordial and admiring; there were remarks not altogether allusive and mysterious to the Frenchman's hoof-shaped shoes--delicate flattery of royal superfluity in toes; and there was no care that certain snarlings at "Mediceans" should be strictly inaudible.

column2: But Lorenzo Tornabuoni possessed that power of dissembling annoyance which is demanded in a man who courts popularity, and Tito, besides his natural disposition to overcome ill-will by good-humour, had the unimpassioned feeling of the alien towards names and details that move the deepest passions of the native.

column2: Arrived where they could get a good oblique view of the Duomo, the party paused.

column2: The festoons and devices placed over the central doorway excited some demur, and Tornabuoni beckoned to Piero di Cosimo, who, as was usual with him at this hour, was lounging in front of Nello's shop. column2: It seemed as if the piazza had been decorated for a real Florentine holiday.

column2: In the van of the crowd were three men in scanty clothing; each had his hands bound together by a cord, and a rope was fastened round his neck and body, in such a way that he who held the extremity of the rope might easily check any rebellious movement by the threat of throttling.
column3: In the van of the crowd were three men in scanty clothing; each had his hands bound together by a cord, and a rope was fastened round his neck and body, in such a way that he who held the extremity of the rope might easily check any rebellious movement by the threat of throttling.

column2: The men who held the ropes were French soldiers, and by broken Italian phrases and strokes from the knotted end of the rope, they from time to time stimulated their prisoners to beg.
column3: The men who held the ropes were French soldiers, and by broken Italian phrases and strokes from the knotted end of the rope, they from time to time stimulated their prisoners to beg.

column2: Lollo had no great compassion for the prisoners, but being conscious of an excellent knife which was his unfailing companion, it had seemed to him from the first that to jump forward, cut a rope, and leap back again before the soldier who held it could use his weapon, would be an amusing and dexterous piece of mischief.
column3: Lollo had no great compassion for the prisoners, but being conscious of an excellent knife which was his unfailing companion, it had seemed to him from the first that to jump forward, cut a rope, and leap back again before the soldier who held it could use his weapon, would be an amusing and dexterous piece of mischief.

column2: And now, when the people began to hoot and jostle more vigorously, Lollo felt that his moment was come--he was close to the eldest prisoner: in an instant he had cut the cord.
column3: And now, when the people began to hoot and jostle more vigorously, Lollo felt that his moment was come-he was close to the eldest prisoner: in an instant he had cut the cord.

column2: He ran at once; but his speed would hardly have sufficed for him if the Florentines had not instantaneously rushed between him and his captor. column3: If there is no other authority in sight they must fall on the sbirri and secure freedom to thieves.

column2: Ah! there is a French soldier: that is more serious."
column3: Ah! there is a French soldier: that is more serious."

column2: The soldier he saw was struggling along on the north side of the piazza, but the object of his pursuit had taken the other direction.
column3: The soldier he saw was struggling along on the north side of the piazza, but the object of his pursuit had taken the other direction.

column2: That object was the eldest prisoner, who had wheeled round the Baptistery and was running towards the Duomo, determined to take refuge in that sanctuary rather than trust to his speed.
column3: That object was the eldest prisoner, who had wheeled round the Baptistery and was running towards the Duomo, determined to take refuge in that sanctuary rather than trust to his speed.

column2: But in mounting the steps, his foot received a shock; he was precipitated towards the group of signori, whose backs were turned to him, and was only able to recover his balance as he clutched one of them by the arm.
column3: But in mounting the steps, his foot received a shock; he was precipitated towards the group of signori, whose backs were turned to him, and was only able to recover his balance as he clutched one of them by the arm.

column2: It was Tito Melema who felt that clutch.
column3: It was Tito Melema who felt that clutch.

column2: He turned his head, and saw the face of his adoptive father, Baldassarre Calvo, close to his own.
column3: He turned his head, and saw the face of his adoptive father, Baldassarre Calvo, close to his own.

column2: The two men looked at each other, silent as death: Baldassarre, with dark fierceness and a tightening grip of the soiled worn hands on the velvet-clad arm; Tito, with cheeks and lips all bloodless, fascinated by terror.
column3: The two men looked at each other, silent as death: Baldassarre, with dark fierceness and a tightening grip of the soiled worn hands on the velvet clad arm; Tito, with cheeks and lips all bloodless, fascinated by terror.

column2: It seemed a long while to them--it was but a moment.
column3: It seemed a long while to them-it was but a moment.

column2: The first sound Tito heard was the short laugh of Piero di Cosimo, who stood close by him and was the only person that could see his face.
column3: The first sound Tito heard was the short laugh of Piero di Cosimo, who stood close by him and was the only person that could see his face.

column2: Ha, ha!	Ha, ha!
column3: true

column2: I know what a ghost should be now."
column3: I know what a ghost should be now."

column2: This is another escaped prisoner, said Lorenzo Tornabuoni.
column3: This is another escaped prisoner, said Lorenzo Tornabuoni.

column2: Who is he, I wonder?
column3: Who is he, I wonder?

column2: _Some madman, surely_, said Tito.
column3: underscore Some madman, surely underscore, said Tito.

column2: He hardly knew how the words had come to his lips: there are moments when our passions speak and decide for us, and we seem to stand by and wonder.
column3: He hardly knew how the words had come to his lips: there are moments when our passions speak and decide for us, and we seem to stand by and wonder.

column2: They carry in them an inspiration of crime, that in one instant does the work of long premeditation.
column3: They carry in them an inspiration of crime, that in one instant does the work of long premeditation.

column2: The two men had not taken their eyes off each other, and it seemed to Tito, when he had spoken, that some magical poison had darted from Baldassarre's eyes, and that he felt it rushing through his veins.
column3: The two men had not taken their eyes off each other, and it seemed to Tito, when he had spoken, that some magical poison had darted from Baldassarre's eyes, and that he felt it rushing through his veins.

column2: But the next instant the grasp on his arm had relaxed, and Baldassarre had disappeared within the church.
column3: But the next instant the grasp on his arm had relaxed, and Baldassarre had disappeared within the church.
